sub_topic: Probability of a certain outcome in a sports game
message_1: A basketball player has a shooting percentage of 75%. If the player takes 20 shots in a game, what is the probability that he will make exactly 15 shots?
message_2:
To find the probability of the basketball player making exactly 15 shots out of 20, we can use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of making exactly k shots
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (n choose k)
- n is the total number of shots (20 in this case)
- k is the number of successful shots (15 in this case)
- p is the probability of making a shot (0.75 in this case)

First, we need to find C(20, 15), which is the number of ways to choose 15 successful shots out of 20:

C(20, 15) = 20! / (15! * (20-15)!)
C(20, 15) = 20! / (15! * 5!)
C(20, 15) = 15504

Now, we can plug the values into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 15) = C(20, 15) * 0.75^15 * (1-0.75)^(20-15)
P(X = 15) = 15504 * 0.75^15 * 0.25^5

P(X = 15) â‰ˆ 0.202

So, the probability that the basketball player will make exactly 15 shots out of 20 is approximately 20.2%.
